question: In stick Euthyoid

question: Vegetarian Breast feeding mother's baby is most likely suffer for deficiency of vit.
desc:
Explanation

Vitamin B12 is found only in animal source so vegetarians are most likely suffer from VitB12 deficiency leading to Megaloblastic anaemia.

question: Shameful exposure of testis
desc:
Explanation

  • Fourniers Gangrene (Idiopathic scrotal gangrene) is form of necrotizing fasciitis with abrupt onset of rapidly fulminating genital gangrene of idiopathic origin and gangrene up to deep fascia.

Predisposing factor

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Local Trauma
  • Paraphimosis
  • Anal infections
  • Immunosupression

Best time for the surgical correction of the undescended testis is 6 months.

Most common tumour of undescended testis is seminoma

Incidence of undescended testis in newborn is 3%

question: In which of the following condition 'Pneumatocele aquarium"
desc:
Explanation

Emphysema aquasum is seen in wet (Typical drowning) where the drowning fluid causes alveolar wall disruption and enters tissue and blood vessels. If dead body is thrown into water due to hydrostatic pressure water passes into lungs known as hydrostatic lung.

question: Most common cause of death in ITP is
desc:
Explanation

  • The primary cause of long-term morbidity and mortality in patients with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is hemorrhage. Spontaneous or accidental trauma-induced intracranial hemorrhage is the most frequent cause of death in association with ITP.

Treatment of ITP

  • In a child with a few scattered petichiae or bruises, platelets count above 20,000/cu mm and no bleeding, only closed observation is required.
  • For children with bleeding treatment includes intravenous immunoglobulin. 1gm/kg/day or anti-D immunoglobulin 50-75mg/kg only in Rh positive children.
  • inj dextamethasone
  • splenectomy

question: Ionotrope of choice in Rt. ventricular dilatation in d/t pulmonary stenosis
desc:
Explanation

  • Positive inotropic agents produce direct hemodynamic benefits by stimulating cardiac contractility as well as by producing peripheral vasodilation.
  • Milrinone is phosphodiesterase III inhibitor that leads to increased cyclic AMP by inhibiting its breakdown. Milrinone may act synergistically with adrenergic agonists to achieve a greater increase in cardiac output than is achieved with either agent alone, and it may also be more effective than dobutamine in increasing cardiac output in the presence of beta blockers.
  • Dobutamine, which is the most commonly acute HF, exerts its effects by stimulating 1 and 2 receptors, with little effect on 1 receptors
  • Ionotropes are used in the short term management of the acute CHF.
  • Dobutamine is a b1 agonist and has no effect on dopamine receptor.

question: Systolic thrill in 2nd and 3rd ICS is palapable in all of the following except
desc:
Explanation

  • Ejection click: Pulmonary stenosis, aortic stenosis and hypertension.
  • Pansystolic murmur: VSD, MR, TR
  • Mitral area- at the apex.
  • Aortic area – 2nd right intercostal space parasternally.
  • Pulmonary area – 2nd left intercostal space parasternaly.
  • Tricuspid area – 4th left intercostal space parasternaly.
  • Neoaortic area or Erb's area – 3rd left intercostal space parasternally. (Early diastolic murmur of ortc regurgitation best heard here)
  • Murmurs originating in the right side of the heart are best heard during inspiration where as murmurs originating on the left side are heard best during expiration. Heart sounds. There are 4 hears sounds viz S1, S2, S3 & S4.
  • A thrill is present with murmurs of grade 4 or greater intensity.
  • The murmur of hypertrophic obstruction cardMOEypathy has features of both obstruction to left ventricular outflow and MR, as would be expected from knowledge of the pathophysiology of this condition.

Thrills are palpable vibrations produced by the murmur.

Congenital cardiac defect associations

Disorder

Defect

Alcohol exposure in utero (fetal alcohol syndrome)

VSD, PDA, ASD, tetralogy of Fallot

Congenital rubella

PDA, pulmonary artery stenosis, septal defects

Down syndrome

AV septal defect (endocardial cushion defect), VSD, ASD

Infant of diabetic mother

Transposition of great vessels

Marfan syndrome

MVP, thoractic aortic aneurysm and dissection, aortic regurgitation

Prenatal Iithium exposure

Ebstein anomaly

Turner syndrome

Bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of aorta

Williams syndrome

Supravalvular aortic stenosis

22q11 syndrome

Truncus arteriosus, tetralogy of fallot
  • Ventricular septal defect: Medium to high pitched soft blowing pan systolic murmur best heard in the left third intercostal space with the diaphragm of the stethoscope during expiration. It does not rediate sometimes a very small defect may produce a loud murmur called as "Maladie de Rogr".

question: Blisters associated with skin rash
desc:
Explanation

  • Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder resulting from the loss of integrity of normal intercellular attachments within the epidermis.

3 types of pemphigus

  1. vulgaris (most common)
  2. foliaceous
  3. vegetans
  • vulgaris is associated with flaccid blisters on either normal appearing skin or erythematous skin.
  • Manual pressure on skin causes elicit the separation of the epidermis (Nikolsky sign).
  • In pemphigus vulgaris antibodies are present against the interceullar substance.
  • Drug induced pemphigus is seen in furesemide.

question: Optic Neuritis in Isonizide toxicity is due to
desc:
Explanation

  • Metabolism of the isoniazide especially by acetylation by N-acetyl transferase. This phenomenon is genetically controlled. Fast actylation requires higher dose and slow acetylors are predisposed to toxicity. (particularly pheripheral neuritis)
  • Isonizid blocks the formation of mycolic acids, which are essential parts of mycrobacterial cell walls. Disruption of the mycobacterial cell wall results in cell death. Isoniazid acts on both intracellular and extracellular mycobacteria.
  • The average plasma concentration of isoniazide in rapid acetylors is about one third to one half of that in slow acetylors.

question: Which of the following is seen OME?
desc:
Explanation

  • Serous ottitis media/secretory ottis media/ottis media with effusion/mucoid ottitis extrana / glue ear / silent ottitis extrana is characterized  by accumulation of non purulent effusion in middle ear cleft.
  • It is common in 2-6 years of age.
  • TM in OME appears dull with thin lesh of blood vessel at periphery, it is yellow and dull grey in colour, light reflex is absent, TM retracted and mobility is restricted.
  • Myringotomy and Glomet insertion is the treatment of choice in OME.

question: 30 years male with crusting from nose nasal obstruction and Russel hazel body is seen. Most likely diagnosis is?
desc:
Explanation

  • Rhinosclerema is a chronic progressive granulomatous disease commencing in the nose and extending into the nasopharynx and oropharynx, larynx (subglottic area), trachea and bronchi.
  • Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis
  • It is characterized by 3 stages: Atropic stage (foul smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting), Granulomatous stage (granulomatous reaction and presence of Mikulicz cells), cicatrial stage.
  • Biopsy shows submucosal infiltrates of plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells and Russel bodies.

Middle cerebral and anterior cerebral  artery is the branch of internal carotid artery.

question: Painless loss of vision is seen in:
desc:
Explanation

Angle closure glaucoma is associated with painful loss of vision.

Primary open angle glaucoma is commonest type of glaucoma that presents with bilateral adult onset of increased IOP (IOP>21 mm or Hg).

Frequent change in presbiopic glasses is seen in open angle glaucoma.

question: A 22 years boy while pushing a truck develops sudden headache, blurring of vision, Kerniks sign positive on fundoscope examination bleeding is seen. Most likely diagnosis is?
desc:
Explanation

SAH may occur spontaneously, usually from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm, or may result from lead injury.

Signs and symptoms of SAH include a severe headache with a rapid onset ("Thunderclap headache"), vomiting, confusion or a lowered level of consciousness, and sometimes seizures. In general the diagnosis is confirmed with a CT scan of the head, or occasionally by lumbar puncture.

Neck stiffness and vomiting are commonly associated with SAH.

MC cause of SAH is Trauma > spontenous rupt ure of Berrys aneurysm.

Manitol is used in head injury to reduce ICP.

question: Which of the following drug is use to delay uterine contraction.
desc:
Explanation

Tocolytics (also called anti-contraction medications or labor represents) are medications used to suppress premature labor (from the Greek tokos, childbirth, and lytic, capable of dissolving). They are green when delivery would result in premature birth.

Tocolytics are drugs that are used to delay your delivery for a short time (up to 48 hours) if you begin labor too early in your pregnancy.

question: Bandle ring is due to
desc:
Explanation

Bandles ring is also called as pathological retraction ring which is formed in case of obstructed labour.

In case of obstructed labour the actively contracting upper segment and passively stretching lower segment of uterus results  into the formation of a ring in between these two segment.

Constriction ring/schroeder's ring: constriction ring is  a form of incordinate uterine contraction where there is localized spastic contraction of ring of circular muscle fiber of uterus.

question: Which of the following is false regarding Paracetamol Poisioning?
wronganswer1: N-acetyl cystine should be started as soon as possible.
wronganswer3: Nomogram should be plotted to identify the toxic and lethal dose.
desc:
Explanation

Paracetamol toxicity is caused by excessive use or overdose of the medication paracetamol (acetaminophen). Most people with paracetamol toxicity have no symptoms in the first 24 hours following overdose. Others may initially  have nonspecific complaints such as vague abdominal pain and nausea. With time, signs of liver injury may devleop; these include low blood sugar, low blood pH, easy bleeding, and hepatic encephalopathy.

The most effective way to dagnosis poisoning is by obtaining a blood paracetamol level. A drug remogram developed in 1975, called the Rumack-Matthew nomogram, estimates the risk of toxicity based on the serum concentration of paracetamol at a given number of hours after ingestion.

Risk of severe liver damage  (ie a peak ALT more than 1000IU/L)

Based  on the dose of paracetamol ingested (mg/kg body weight):

Less than 150mg/kg – unlikely.

More than 250mg/kg – likely.

More than 12g total – potentially fatal.

NAC is believed work by a number of protective mechanism. It acts as a precursor for glutathione, promoting normal conjugation of any remaining paracetamol, and also supplies thiols that function as antioxidants. It is virtually 100% effective in preventing liver damage when given within eight hours of ingestion

Pralidoxime is typically used in case of organophosphate poisoning.

Pralidoxime has an important role in reversing paralysis of the respiratory muscles but due to its poor blood-brain barrier penetration, it has little effect on centrally mediated respiratory depression.

question: In counaids classification zone I refers to
desc:
Explanation

Segment I: Caudate lobe, segment IV: Quadrate lobe.

Liver can store maximum of 65 gm of glycogen/kg of liver tissue.

Functionally, the liver can be divided into three zones, based upon oxygen supply. Zone 1 encircles the portal tracts where the oxygenated blood from hepatic arteries enters. Zone 3 is locatded around central veins, where oxygenation is poor. Zone 2 is located in between.

It should not be confused with the anatomic lobes of the liver (caudate lobe, quadrate lobe, left lobe, and right lobe)

question: Dorsal mesogastrium develops into
desc:
Explanation

The portion of the dorsal mesentery that attaches to the greater curvature of the stomach, is known as the dorsal mesogastrium. The part of the dorsal mesentery that suspends the colon is termed the mesocolon.

The dorsal mesogastrium  develops into the greater omentum.

question: PAIR is done for
desc:
Explanation

The PAIR (puncture –aspiration-injection-reaspiration) procedure is a noninvasive treatment option to remove hydatid cysts. PAIR is considered an alternative treatment for cystic Echinococcosis (hydatid disease) and is often indicated for patients who do not respond to surger or Benzimidazoles.

The PAIR procedure can be performed as follows:

ultrasound-guided percutaneous puncture of the cyst

Aspiration of cystic fluid

Injection of a scolicidal solution

reaspiration of the solution

desc:

Octreotide is often given as an infusion for management of acute haemorrhage from esophageal varices in liver cirrhosis on the basis that it reduces portal venous pressure, though current evidence suggests that this effect is transient and does not improve survival.

Investigation of choice in UGI bleeding is Endoscopy.

Esophygeal varices is most commonly associated with painless massive bleeding.

Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis is caused by adenovirus.

question: A 8.5 yr boy with alleged h/o humping following which he is c/o pain in his right hip and pain in Rt. knee joint as well. No other significant history other than painful movement at abduction & internal rotation. Severity of pain increase during sleep & during walking. The most likely dx is
desc:
Explanation

Perthes  disease is a painful disorder of childhood characterized by avascular necrosis of femoral head.

The patient is typically a boy 4-8 years complains of pain and start limping, symptoms continue for weeks on end or may reoccur intermittently.

question: Which of the following is true about succinyl choline?
rightanswer: Shouldn't be use in muscular Dystrphy
desc:
Explanation

Succinyl choline is the only depolarizing (non competitive) muscle relaxant in clinical use. It is the shortest  acting muscle relaxant.

Rapid onset of action : 30-60 second, ultrasound (shortest) duration of action: 3-5 min (>10min)

Sch is relatively safe drug but there is risk of hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, cardiac arrest (profound bradycardia) in children with undiagnosed Myopathies.

Sch may leads to hyperkalemia which leads to diastolic  cardiac arrest refractory to CPR.

Post anaesthetic muscle soreness is due to suxamethonium.

question: Which of the following Stimulates Hydrochloride secretion in stomach?
desc:
Explanation

Gastrin is secreated by Gcell of stomach which stimulates oxyntic / parietal cell to produce HCl.

question: 45 year female presented to OPD with CXR - Showing globular heart with no SOB, Most likely diagnosis is?
desc:
Explanation

Rapid accumulation of fluid or blood in the pericardial space causing increase in the intrapericardial pressure is called as cardiac tamponade.

This results in compression of cardiac chambers.

¯

venous return

¯

cardiac output

Cardiac tamponade, also known as pericardial tamponade, is a type of pericardial effusion in which fluid, pus, blood, clots, or gas accumulates in the pericardium (the sac in which the heart is enclosed), resulting in slow or rapid compression of the heart.

Signs of classical cardiac tamponade include three signs, known as Beck's triad. Low blood pressure occurs because of decreased stroke volume, jugularvenous distension due to impaired venous return to the heart, and muffled heart sounds due to fluid buildup inside the pericardium.

A large cardiac tamponade will show as an enlarged globular - shaped heart on chest x-ray.

question: Hernia from lateral boarder of external oblique, latisimus dorsi, and iliac creast is:
desc:
Explanation

 

LUMBAR HERNIA

It is herniation either through superior or inferior lumbar triangle.

Superior lumbar triangle (Grynfelt's / Lesgaft's triangle) is bounded by sacrospinalis, 12th rib and posterior border of internal oblique.

Inferior lumbar triangle is bounded by latissimus dorsi, external oblique and iliac crest (triangle of Petit).

Lumbar hernia is common through inferior  lumbar triangle.

Inguinal hernia is the commonest hernia (73%) because the muscular anatomy in the inguinal region is weak and also due to the presence of natural weakness like deep ring and cord structures.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in the external oblique aponeurosis and is 1.25 cm above the pubic tubercle

Deep inguinal ring is a U-shaped condensation of the transversalis fascia, lies 1.25 cm above the inguinal ligament midway between the symphysis pubis and the anterior superior iliac spine.

Contents of Sac

Omentum - Omentocele (Epiplocele). Difficult to reduce the sac later, initially it can be reduced easily.

Intestine - Enterocele - commonly small bowel, but sometimes even large bowel.

Difficult to reduce the sac initially.

Richter's hernia: A portion of circumference of bowel is the content.

Urinary bladder may be the content or part of the posterial wall of the sac-cystocele.

Ovary, often with fallopian tube.

Meckel's diverticulum - Littre's hernia.

question: Remanent of gubernaculum in females.
desc:
Explanation

The gubernaculum is present only during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs, being replaced by distinct vestiges in makes and females.

In Males:

The upper part of the gubernaculum degenerates.

The lower part persists as the gubernaculum testis ("scrotal ligament"). This ligament secures the testis to the most inferior portion of the scrotum, tethering it in place and limiting the degree to which the testis can move within the scrotum.

In Females:

The gubernaculum has two vestigial remants in females, the ovarian ligament and the round ligament of the uterus (ligamentum teres uteri (which respectively serve to support the ovaries and uterus in the pelvis.

Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens. A fold of peritoneum develops at the junction of vas deferences and epididymis which can be traced down upto the developing phallus (scrotum) and is called as gubernaculum.

Along with some hormonal factors, the muscular fibres in the gubernaculum assist in the descent of testis.

question: Which of the following is easily treatable Spasmodic Menarcheal dysmenorrhoea?
desc:
Explanation

Dysmenorrhea, also known as dysmenorrhoea, painful periods, or menstrual cramps, is pain during menstruation.

Dysmenorrhea can be classified as either primary or secondary based on the absence or presence of an underlying cause. Secondary dysmenorrhea is dysmenorrhea which is associated with an existing condition.

The most common cause of secondary dysmenorrhea is endometriosis.

question: A 20 years lady at 28 WOG while pushing her can c/o pain lower abdomen, hold her abdomen cries holding her abdomen with no SOB. Immediate management will be?
rightanswer: i.v. with wide bore canula and sends for cross matching.
desc:
Explanation

This is a case  of APH i.e. concealed hemorrhage where there is severe abdominal pain.

In such case blood transfusion is the main modality of treatment and iv crystalloids can also be given to correct hypovolumia.

Painless vaginal bleeding with soft and non tender uterus is the clinical feature of placenta previa.

Abruptio placenta is characterized by pain, tender and tense uterus.

Slowing of fetal heart rate on passing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on release of pressure is termed as stallworthy's sign.

question: Pyriformis disease is due to pathology of
desc:
Explanation

Piriformis syndrome is a neuromuscular disorder that occurs when the sciatic nerve is compressed or otherwise irritated by thepiriformis muscle causing pain, tingling and numbness in the buttocks and along the path of the sciatic nerve descending the lower thigh and into the leg.

question: While doing doplar scan 50% of right renal artery is stenosed. Then blood flow to rt. kidney will
desc:
Explanation

According to poisiles law

th of original

Renal artery stenosis (RAS) is most commonly caused by either fibromuscular dysplasia or atherosclerosis, and it may occur alone (isolated anatomical RAS) or associated with hypertension renal insufficiency (ischemic nephropathy) or both.

question: Baby with 4 days old fever and measles like rash dx is
desc:
Explanation

Measles (rubeola) virus

A paramyxovirus that causes measles. Usually presentation involves prodromal fever with cough, coryza and conjunctivitis, then eventually Kopilk spots (bright red spots with blue-white centre on buccal mucosa), followed 1-2 days later by a maculopapular rash that starts at the head/neck and spreads downward. Lymphadentitis with warthin-finkeldey giant cells (fused lymphocytes) in a background of paracortical hyperplasia. SSPE (subacute scloreosing panencephalitis, occurring years later) encephalitis (1:2000), and giant cell pneumonia (rarely, in immune suppressed) and possible sequelae.

3C's measles

Caugh

Coryza

Conjunctivitis

Vitamin

supplementation can reduce morbidity and mortality from measles, particularly in malnourished children

question: Repeated stress causes cell to adapt in unfavorable condition called
desc:
Explanation

Cellular changes

Hyperplasia

Incerase in number of cells. May be a risk factor for future malignancy (eg. endometrial hyperplasia) but not considered permalignant

Hypertrophy

increase in size of cells

Atrophy

Decrease in tissue mass due to decrease in size and / or number of cells. Causes include disuse, denervation, loss of blood supply, loss of hormonal stimulation, poor nutrition

Dysplasia

Replacement of one cell type to another. Usually due to exposure to an irritant, such as gastric acid or cigarette smoke. Reversible if the irritant is removed but may undergo malignant transformation with persistent insult (eg. Barrett esophagus® esophageal adenocarcinoma)

Neoplasia

Uncontrolled, clonal proliferation of cells. Can be bengin or malignant

Analasia

Complete lack of differentiation of cells in a malignant neoplasm.

Differentiation

The degree to which a malignant tumor resembles its tissue of origin: Well differentiated tumors (often less aggressive) closely resemble their tissue of origin.

question: Hypertrophy means
wronganswer2: increase cell size due to adaptation.
wronganswer1: increase cell number due to multiplication.
wronganswer3: increase in cell size due to multiplication.
rightanswer: increase cell size due to internal stimuli.
desc:
Explanation

Hypertrophy

Increase in cell size

Causes of hypertrophy

Increase workload

Left ventricular Hypertrophy in response to an increase in afterload (resistence) or preload (volume).

Skeletal muscle hypertrophy in weight training.

Smooth muscle hypertrophy in the urinary bladder in response to urethral obstruction (eg. prostate hyperplasia)

Surgical removal of one kidney with compensatory hypertrophy (and hyerplasia) of the other kidney.

Cell enlargement in cytomegalovirus infections.

question: A patient presented with Cyst on neck. Which moves with the tongue protrusion? The operation done for this condition is
desc:
Explanation

Thyroglossal cyst is a swelling occurring in the neck in any part along the line of thyroglossal tract.

Thyroglossal cyst Moves with deglutition as well as with the protrusion of tongue.

Sistrunk operation is the operation of choice for Thyroglossal cyst.

Sistrunk operation: Excision of cyst and also full tract upto the foramen caecum is done along with removal of central part of the hyoid bone, as the tract passes through it.

question: Which of the following is true of chrons disease?
wronganswer1: Resection of the infected part is treatment of choice
wronganswer3: Involves mucosa and sub mucosa only.
rightanswer: Smoking increases the incidence of CD.
desc:
Explanation

Chrons disease:

No sex predilection

Smoking is a risk factor

Majority (>75%) of cases occur between 11 and 35 years of age

It has Transmural involvement.

Involvement: Terminal ileum alone (30% of cases), ileum and colon (50% of cases), colon alone (205 cases). Involves other areas of GI tract (mouth to anus)

Thick bowel wall and narrow lumen (leads to obstruction)

Aphthous ulcers in bowel (early sign)

Skin lesions, strictures, fistulas Deep linear ulcers with cobblestone pattern, Fat creeping  around serosa

Noncaseating granulomas (60% of cases).

question: Dependence is seen with
desc:
Explanation

Barbiturates has both GABA mimetic as well as GAB facilatory action to increase the duration of CI-channel opening.

Barbiturates has high abuse liability and may precipitate withdrawal syndromes.

If poisoning occur no specific antidote is available.

Barbiturates are contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

Similar to benzodiazepines the longer acting barbiturates produce a less severe withdrawal syndrome than short acting and ultra short acting barbiturates.

question: Which of the following helps in bone mineralization?
desc:
Explanation

Vitamin D helps in intestinal absorption of calcium and bone mineralization.

Vitamin D

D2 = ergocalciferol = ingested from plants.

D3 = cholecalciferol - consumed in milk, formed in sun-exposed skin (stratum basale).

25-OHD3 =storage form

1,25-(OH)2D3 (calcitriol) = active form.

Function

Increase intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate, ­ bone mineralization at low levels, ­ bone respiration at higher levels

Deficiency

Rickets in children (bone pain and deformity), osteomalacia in adults (bone pain and muscle  weakness), hypocalcemia tetany. Breastfed infants should receive oral vitamin D. Difficiency is exacerbated by low sun exposure, pigmented skin prematurity.

question: Which of the following causes ¯Ca+2 level absorption in body
desc:
Explanation

Parathormone stimulates the osteoclastic activities and hence increases the blood calcium level.

Calcitonin or Thyrocalcitonin decreases serum Ca+ which is done by depositing Ca+2 in bone.

Tetany is a clinical condition characterized by neuromuscular hyperexcitability due to decreased Ca+2 level in blood.

Steroid receptor antagonist

question: A patient with platelets < 50,000 and tear drop cells in PBS most likely dx is ?
desc:
Explanation

Schistocytes are erythrocyte fragments (helmet cells are a type of schistocyte); hemolytic anemias or traumatic hemolysis. Bite cells are erythrocytes with "bites" of cytoplasm being removed by splenic macrophages; they may be seen in G6PD deficiency. Teardrop cells (dacrocytes) may be seen in thalassemia and myelofibrosis. Sickle cells (drepanocytes) are seen in sickle cell anemia. Rouleaux (stack of coins) refers to erythrocytes lining up in a row.

Rouleaux are characteristic of multiple myeloma.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP; also termed idiopathic thromobocytopenic purpura) is an acquired disorder in which there is immune-mediated destruction of platelets and possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. In children, it is usually an acute disease, most commonly following an infection and with a self-limited course.

Common physical findings of ITP include the following:

Nonpalpable petechiae, which mostly occur in dependent regions

Hemorrhagic bullae on mucous membranes

PUrpura

Gingival bleeding

Signs of GI bleeding

Menometrorrhagia, menorrhagia

Retinal hemorrhages

Evidence of intracranial hemorrhage, with possible neurologic symptoms

Nonpalpable spleen: The prevalence of palpable spleen in patients with ITP is approximately the same as that in the non-ITP population (ie, 3% in adults, 12% in children).

Spontaneous, bleeding when platelet count is less than 20,000/mm3.

Isolated thrombocytopenia on a complete blood cell count (CBC) is the key laboratory finding of ITP.

question: Difference between selective and non selective COX2 inhibitor
desc:
Explanation

Selective COX2 inhibitors (celecoxib, rofecoxib, valdecoxib) has very little GI toxicity.

COX1 is constitutive, COX2 is inducible (synthesis is stimulated by endotoxin and other inflammatory mediator). COX3 is recently isolated from cerebral cortex and it is involved in pain perception and fever.

question: Hypoxia causes which vasoconstriction
desc:
Explanation

Pulmonary vasculature is unique in that hypoxia causes vasoconstriction so that only well ventilated areas are perused. In other organ hypoxia causes vasodilation.

question: Structure passing through esophageal opening of diaphragm
desc:
Explanation

Oesophygeal opening transmits oesophagus, oesophygeal branch of left gastric artery, gastric and vagus nerve.

question: Hypocalcemia is side effect of
desc:
Explanation

Furosemide posses vasodilatory action which is responsible for the quick relief in LVF and pulmonary edema.

Loop diuretics has natriuretic effect. They act by inhibiting Na+K+2Cl - sympoters.

Loop diuretics causes excretion of Ca+2, therefore use in the treatment of hypercalcemia.

question: Trachea not shifted in
desc:
Explanation

In chest x-ray PA and lateral view 40% of the lung field is obscured by other structure including ribs.

All the fissures are visible in lateral view.

B/1 hilar lymphadenopathy with peripheral (egg- cell) calcification seen in silicosis.

Trail's sign: It is the undue prominence of the clavicular head of sternomastoid on the side to which the trachea is deviated.

The mediastinum may be pushed away from the affected side (contralateral deviation) by a pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Fibrosis or collapse of the lung will pull the mediastinum towards the affected side( ipsilateral deviation).

question: Opiod analgesic of choice in severe painful operative procedures
desc:
Explanation

Sufentanil is a synthetic opioid analgesic drug approximately five to 10 times more potent than its parent drug, fentanyl, and 500 times as potent as morphine.

Sufentanil is the most potent whereas meperidine (Pethidine) and propoxyphene are the least potent opoids.

receptors of opoids have dependence producing actions due to euphoric action.

Miosis can occur with morphine use and pin point pupil is a valuable sign in the diagnosis of opoid poisioning

question: Best method of health education for adoption of new family planning methods for newly married couple is?
desc:
Explanation

Group Methods of Health Education Demonstration

Meaning and definition

Demonostration is the process of providing knowledge and skills well as developing attitude of a small group of people through the manipulation of appropriate teaching devices or materials. Teaching by demonstration involves verbal and visual explanation. It is a mixture of theoretical and practical teaching. It is organized to teach about the specific topics and it takes 45 minutes to complete the demonstration but it slightly vary according to the topic. The numbers of learners in the group may be about 15 to the maximum. The learners are given opportunity to see and manipulate the device or materials used in demonstration and also give opportunity to practice the process and questions and answers to calrify doubts.

Advantages

It is the effective teaching method which involves varied learning experiences like seeing, hearing, feeling, testing and smelling depending upon the subject of demonstration.

It is interesting and draws attention of the learners because of the active learning process.

It helps to develop not only knowledge and attitude but also skills for required work performance.

Student's achievement could be immediately assessed through verbal expression and skill practice.

Provides concrete and realistic visual picture of what is being taught resulting in a more lasting impression.

It is cheap, practicable, accessible and useful for different categories of learners. It needs only limited materials and object. It can be used at different teaching-learning situations at different places.

question: Glutton/Heliotropic rach is commonly seen in
desc:
Explanation

Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) is an intensely puritic, papulovesicular skin disease characterized by lesions symmetrically distributed over exterior surfaces (i.e. elbows, knees, buttocks, back, scalp, and posterior neck).

question: 11 years child presented with history of mass in left thigh. The mass seems arising from the diaphysis of the femur, involving the soft tissue of thigh. The child is having fever also. Most probable diagnosis.
desc:
Explanation

It is a highly malignant undifferentiated pheripheral primitive neuro ectodermal tumour occurring most commonly diaphysis of femur, fibula or other long bone in 10-20 years.

Periosteal new bone formation also known as onion peel appearance is seen in ewings sarcoma.

50% of tumour metastatises to lung & 25% to bone and bone marrow.

question: In rheumatoid arthritis, pathology starts in the
desc:
Explanation

Rheumatoid arthritis is immunologically mediated chronic multisystemic disease of unknown cause with characteristic feature of persistent inflammatory synovitis.

It usually involves the peripheral joints symmetrically.

Pathology commonly starts from synovium and it progressively involve articular cartilage.

Commonly involved joint in Rheumatoid arthritis is wrist joint, Metacarpophalangeal (MP) joint and Proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) Whereas Distal inter phalangeal jointis never involved.
